history.content:
If you don't care about receiving a NP (assuming you PNPed your one class) and you don't have other problems preventing you from taking classes Fall 2021, then I would just take the NP and stay enrolled in Fall 2021. Btw, if you're not planning on grad school, an NP literally doesn't matter. Even if you are considering grad school, you'll be able to explain on your application your personal circumstances that led you to drop all your classes except 1, and they'll understand. 

If you have other problems that you need time resolving (ie. health issues, financial issues) I would strongly recommend taking the gap year. I'm not sure how much lower your response rate from recruiters will be for internships (it will probably be lower, but you'll definitely still get coding challenges). Edit: actually, it seems like you weren't planning on doing an internship this summer. If that's the case, you don't actually have to indicate on your resume that you took a gap year, so your response rate will not change. 

Above all though, if you do have a mental health issue (burnout, depression, etc.), I would strongly recommend prioritizing your recovery. 

Your wellbeing >>>> a potential increase in recruiter response rate

Even if you are considering grad school, you'll be able to explain on your application your personal circumstances that led you to drop all your classes except 1, and they'll understand. 

If you have other problems that you need time resolving (ie. health issues, financial issues) I would strongly recommend taking the gap year. I'm not sure how much lower your response rate from recruiters will be for internships (it will probably be lower, but you'll definitely still get coding challenges). 

Above all though, if you do have a mental health issue (burnout, depression, etc.), I would strongly recommend prioritizing your recovery. 

Your wellbeing >>>> a potential increase in recruiter response rate

children.subject:
Just indicate on your resume that your expected graduation date is May 202x (whatever your new one is) instead of writing your dates of attendance. Only recruiters for companies which ask for your transcript (Google is the only big company ik that does this) will see that you took a gap year. 99% of recruiters won't know. 

Once you're in the interview stage, you should of course tell your interviewer you took a gap year if that comes up, but at that point they won't care - only your interview performance matters.

Thank you for the thorough response! I just regret that I could've done better and finish other classes that I really wish to finish this semester. Could you elaborate on why I don't have to indicate I have a gap year? The recuiters will see that I extended my graduate date right?

history.content:
I did really bad on spring 2021(dropped almost all of my classes, end up only taking one) and want to withdraw this semester. However, I realized that I have made this decision too late and if I withdraw now I would be dropped from all of my currently enrolled classes(cs61c for summer 21; cs189 and 161 for fall 21). All cs classes that I haven't taken yet are full, if I withdraw spring 2021 that means chances are large that I would not take any cs classes fall 2021. So I kinda want to withdraw both spring and fall 2021 and extend graduation date by a year. And since I'm a rising junior without any personal projects and internship experience,  I plan to spend fall 2021 working on applying for internships and personal projects. 

Now things I'm worried about is whether recruiters would care about the gap year I take when applying for internships during fall 2021 and limit my future chances of getting an offer. Should I just not withdraw any semester and move on? Could anyone give me some insights? Thank you!
history.subject: Good idea to take a gap semester for fall 2021?
